<h1 class="firstHeading no_toc"><a href="https://www.wikihow.com/Steam-Your-Face">How to Steam Your Face</a></h1>
<div class="ss_check" id="expert_coauthor">
	
	Co-authored by <a class="expert_icon expert_coauthor_link" href="#article_info_section">
		Ashley Adams</a>
</div>
<p class="vertical_toc" id="method_toc">
<span>Explore this Article</span>
<a class="toc_method" href="#Steaming_Your_Face_sub" id="">Steaming Your Face</a>
<a class="toc_method" href="#Experimenting_With_Different_Steams_sub" id="">Experimenting With Different Steams</a>

<div id="sp_icon_body">
		This article was co-authored by <a href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=ashleyadams#ashleyadams">Ashley Adams</a>. Ashley Adams is a Licensed Cosmetologist and Hair Stylist in Illinois. She completed her Cosmetology education at John Amico School of Hair Design in 2016.<br/><br/>There are <a href="#references">11 references</a> cited in this article, which can be found at the bottom of the page.
		
	</div>
</div>
<p>Steam treatments open your pores and increase circulation, leaving your skin clean, flushed, and glowing. If you want an easy way to look refreshed, you can steam your face at home! You can even add scents to a steam treatment to create your own aromatherapy session.</p>

</div>
<h2 class="hidden"><span class="mw-headline" id="Steps">Steps</span></h2>
<a class="anchor" name="Steaming_Your_Face_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky steps_first">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>1</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Steaming_Your_Face">Steaming Your Face</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_1">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Steam-Your-Face-Step-1.jpg?ajax=true&aid=255279" href="#/Image:Steam-Your-Face-Step-1.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Steam Your Face Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1f/Steam-Your-Face-Step-1.jpg/aid255279-v4-728px-Steam-Your-Face-Step-1.jpg" height="546" id="img_3b69110e20" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_3b69110e20')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Steam Your Face Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1f/Steam-Your-Face-Step-1.jpg/aid255279-v4-728px-Steam-Your-Face-Step-1.jpg" width="728"/></noscript>
<script>WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');</script></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Bring a small pot of water to a boil.</b> A basic steam involves nothing but water and your skin. It doesn't require much water. Fill up a small pot with 1 - 2 cups of water and bring it to a full boil.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 1" class="reference" id="_ref-1"><a href="#_note-1">[1]</a></sup>
<script>WH.performance.mark('step1_rendered');</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Steam-Your-Face-Step-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=255279" href="#/Image:Steam-Your-Face-Step-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Steam Your Face Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f8/Steam-Your-Face-Step-2.jpg/aid255279-v4-728px-Steam-Your-Face-Step-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_46bfc57afb" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_46bfc57afb')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Steam Your Face Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f8/Steam-Your-Face-Step-2.jpg/aid255279-v4-728px-Steam-Your-Face-Step-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Wash your face.</b> While the water is heating up, wash your face using a gentle cleanser. Be sure to remove all of your makeup and any dirt, oil or sweat that's sitting on the surface of your skin. It's important that your skin be clean when you steam it. Your pores will open wide, and if you have dirt or makeup on your skin, it could cause irritation.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 2" class="reference" id="_ref-2"><a href="#_note-2">[2]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Don't wash your face with an exfoliating scrub or harsh soap. Before a steam, it's best to wash with a very mild cleanser, to reduce the chance that the steam treatment will further irritate your skin.</li>
<li>Pat your face dry with a soft towel.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Steam-Your-Face-Step-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=255279" href="#/Image:Steam-Your-Face-Step-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Steam Your Face Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b4/Steam-Your-Face-Step-3.jpg/aid255279-v4-728px-Steam-Your-Face-Step-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_987e499248" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_987e499248')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Steam Your Face Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b4/Steam-Your-Face-Step-3.jpg/aid255279-v4-728px-Steam-Your-Face-Step-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Pour the steaming water into a bowl.</b> If you're doing the steam treatment as part of an at-home spa treatment, pour it into a big, pretty ceramic or glass bowl. If you just want a quick steam, you can leave it in the pot. Place whatever vessel you're using on a few folded towels on top of a table.

<ul>
<li>Don't pour the water into a plastic bowl. You don't want small plastic molecules getting involved in your facial steam.</li>
<li>Be very careful that you do not burn yourself! If you decide to leave the water in the pot, then make sure to remove it from the heat source before using it.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Steam-Your-Face-Step-4.jpg?ajax=true&aid=255279" href="#/Image:Steam-Your-Face-Step-4.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Steam Your Face Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/ac/Steam-Your-Face-Step-4.jpg/aid255279-v4-728px-Steam-Your-Face-Step-4.jpg" height="546" id="img_5171274d5d" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_5171274d5d')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Steam Your Face Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/ac/Steam-Your-Face-Step-4.jpg/aid255279-v4-728px-Steam-Your-Face-Step-4.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Add essential oils or herbs.</b> Now's the time to add essential oils or herbs to the water to make the treatment a little special. If you add oils or herbs, the steam treatment will double as an aromatherapy session, so it will be a 2-in-1 treatment. Just a few drops of essential oils goes a long way.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 3" class="reference" id="_ref-3"><a href="#_note-3">[3]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Be sure to add any extras after you've taken the water off the boil. Otherwise, the scents will quickly evaporate.</li>
<li>If you don't have any special oils or herbs, try tea! Put a few herbal tea bags in the water. Chamomile, mint, and chai all make excellent steams.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Steam-Your-Face-Step-5.jpg?ajax=true&aid=255279" href="#/Image:Steam-Your-Face-Step-5.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Steam Your Face Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/44/Steam-Your-Face-Step-5.jpg/aid255279-v4-728px-Steam-Your-Face-Step-5.jpg" height="546" id="img_a6ea4a9a26" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_a6ea4a9a26')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Steam Your Face Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/44/Steam-Your-Face-Step-5.jpg/aid255279-v4-728px-Steam-Your-Face-Step-5.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Steam your face with a towel over your head.</b> Drape the towel over your head so that it drops down on either side of your face, trapping the steam so that it concentrates near your skin. Place your face close enough to the steaming water to feel it massaging your face, but not so close that your skin feels like it's burning or you're having trouble breathing fresh air.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 4" class="reference" id="_ref-4"><a href="#_note-4">[4]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>A typical steam lasts about 10 minutes, so you may want to sit down while you do the treatment. However, keep in mind that you can receive many of the same benefits if you stop after 5 minutes.</li>
<li>Don't steam your face for much longer than 10 minutes, especially if you have acne or other skin issues. Steaming causes the face to swell, and it can exacerbate acne if done for too much time.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Steam-Your-Face-Step-6.jpg?ajax=true&aid=255279" href="#/Image:Steam-Your-Face-Step-6.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Steam Your Face Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/90/Steam-Your-Face-Step-6.jpg/aid255279-v4-728px-Steam-Your-Face-Step-6.jpg" height="546" id="img_4f0b3e7a5a" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_4f0b3e7a5a')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Steam Your Face Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/90/Steam-Your-Face-Step-6.jpg/aid255279-v4-728px-Steam-Your-Face-Step-6.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 6" class="step_num">6</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_6"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Draw the dirt from your pores with a mask.</b> The steam treatment leaves your pores wide open, making this the perfect time to draw out the dirt and other impurities. The best way to do so is to follow your steam treatment with a clay mask. Smooth the mask over your face and let it sit for 10-15 minutes. Wash it away with warm water and pat your face dry with a towel.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 5" class="reference" id="_ref-5"><a href="#_note-5">[5]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>You can purchase a clay mask in the beauty section of your grocery store, drug store, or large store, such as Target or Walmart.</li>
<li>If you don't have a clay mask, use plain honey or a combination of honey and oatmeal.</li>
<li>If you choose not to use a mask, you can simply wash your face with warm water after the steam treatment.</li>
<li>Don't use a strong exfoliant on your skin after steaming, especially if you have acne. Since your face will be slightly swollen and your pores will be open, scrubbing it could cause it to become inflamed.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Steam-Your-Face-Step-7.jpg?ajax=true&aid=255279" href="#/Image:Steam-Your-Face-Step-7.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Steam Your Face Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/dd/Steam-Your-Face-Step-7.jpg/aid255279-v4-728px-Steam-Your-Face-Step-7.jpg" height="546" id="img_c5ecd0569f" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_c5ecd0569f')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Steam Your Face Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/dd/Steam-Your-Face-Step-7.jpg/aid255279-v4-728px-Steam-Your-Face-Step-7.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 7" class="step_num">7</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_7"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Tone your face.</b> After you rinse your mask away, use a facial toner to help your pores close back up. Apply it to your face in gentle strokes using a cotton ball.

<ul>
<li>Lemon juice makes a great natural toner. Mix 1 tablespoon with 1 cup of water.</li>
<li>Apple cider vinegar is another great option. Mix 1 tablespoon with 1 cup of water.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Steam-Your-Face-Step-8.jpg?ajax=true&aid=255279" href="#/Image:Steam-Your-Face-Step-8.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Steam Your Face Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/52/Steam-Your-Face-Step-8.jpg/aid255279-v4-728px-Steam-Your-Face-Step-8.jpg" height="546" id="img_e95d0a4382" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_e95d0a4382')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Steam Your Face Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/52/Steam-Your-Face-Step-8.jpg/aid255279-v4-728px-Steam-Your-Face-Step-8.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 8" class="step_num">8</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_8"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Moisturize your face.</b> Steam and heat cause the skin to dry out, so it's important to follow your treatment with a good moisturizer. Use one made with soothing oils, aloe and butters that will prevent your skin from getting too dry. Let the moisturizer completely absorb into your skin before applying makeup.

</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-apsload="1" data-channels="8161489800,4805470868" data-lateload="0" data-loaded="1" data-service="adsense" data-slot="7750426266" data-viewablerefresh="1">

</div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Experimenting_With_Different_Steams_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>2</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Experimenting_With_Different_Steams">Experimenting With Different Steams</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_2">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Steam-Your-Face-Step-9.jpg?ajax=true&aid=255279" href="#/Image:Steam-Your-Face-Step-9.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Steam Your Face Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/87/Steam-Your-Face-Step-9.jpg/aid255279-v4-728px-Steam-Your-Face-Step-9.jpg" height="546" id="img_ba16e47554" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_ba16e47554')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Steam Your Face Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/87/Steam-Your-Face-Step-9.jpg/aid255279-v4-728px-Steam-Your-Face-Step-9.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Do a cold relief steam.</b> There's no clear evidence that steaming your face can help with a cold.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 6" class="reference" id="_ref-6"><a href="#_note-6">[6]</a></sup> However, this is a common home remedy to relieve sinus pressure associated with a cold, and there is minimal evidence that it may be effective in some individuals.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 7" class="reference" id="_ref-7"><a href="#_note-7">[7]</a></sup> If you want to try a cold relief steam, follow the steps above using one or more of the following herbs and essential oils:

<ul>
<li>
<b>Herbs</b>: Chamomile, mint or eucalyptus</li>
<li>
<b>Oils</b>: mint, eucalyptus or bergamot</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Steam-Your-Face-Step-10.jpg?ajax=true&aid=255279" href="#/Image:Steam-Your-Face-Step-10.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Steam Your Face Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0f/Steam-Your-Face-Step-10.jpg/aid255279-v4-728px-Steam-Your-Face-Step-10.jpg" height="546" id="img_e6e1bd910e" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_e6e1bd910e')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Steam Your Face Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0f/Steam-Your-Face-Step-10.jpg/aid255279-v4-728px-Steam-Your-Face-Step-10.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Do a stress relief steam.</b> Steaming soothes the soul as well as the skin, which is one of the reasons why it's a popular treatment at spas. A facial steam feels especially good when you're stressed out and can take the time to breathe in some wonderful scents while you sit back and relax. Try one or more of the following herbs and oils for a soothing, stress-relieving steam:<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 8" class="reference" id="_ref-8"><a href="#_note-8">[8]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>
<b>Herbs</b>: Lavender, lemon verbena, chamomile</li>
<li>
<b>Oils</b>: Passionflower, bergamot, sandalwood</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Steam-Your-Face-Step-11.jpg?ajax=true&aid=255279" href="#/Image:Steam-Your-Face-Step-11.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Steam Your Face Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/75/Steam-Your-Face-Step-11.jpg/aid255279-v4-728px-Steam-Your-Face-Step-11.jpg" height="546" id="img_f7f74ee8ef" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_f7f74ee8ef')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Steam Your Face Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/75/Steam-Your-Face-Step-11.jpg/aid255279-v4-728px-Steam-Your-Face-Step-11.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Do an invigorating steam.</b> A steam can help you feel awake and refreshed if you do it first thing in the morning, particularly if you use scents that have an energizing effect. For a rejuvenating steam, use one or more of these herbs and oils:

<ul>
<li>
<b>Herbs</b>: Lemon balm, peppermint, ginseng</li>
<li>
<b>Oils</b>: Cedarwood, lemongrass, orange, grapefruit, eucalyptus<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 9" class="reference" id="_ref-9"><a href="#_note-9">[9]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage final_li">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Steam-Your-Face-Step-12.jpg?ajax=true&aid=255279" href="#/Image:Steam-Your-Face-Step-12.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Steam Your Face Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0c/Steam-Your-Face-Step-12.jpg/aid255279-v4-728px-Steam-Your-Face-Step-12.jpg" height="546" id="img_f1d69bfc0f" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_f1d69bfc0f')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Steam Your Face Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0c/Steam-Your-Face-Step-12.jpg/aid255279-v4-728px-Steam-Your-Face-Step-12.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Do a steam for sleep aid.</b> Doing a steam a few minutes before you go to bed can help you relax and sleep peacefully. Try using one or more of these herbs and oils to help you get to sleep more easily next time you have insomnia:<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 10" class="reference" id="_ref-10"><a href="#_note-10">[10]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>
<b>Herbs</b>: Valerian, chamomile, lavender</li>
<li>
<b>Oils</b>: Lavender, patchouli, geranium rose</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>

</div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Questions_and_Answers_sub"></a>
<div class="qa section sticky qa_show_unanswered_questions" data-aid="255279" data-few_contribs="1" data-search_enabled="0">
<h2>
<div class="altblock"></div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="qa_headline">Community Q&A</span>
</h2>
<div class="section_text" id="qa">
<div id="qa_answered_questions_container">
<div id="qa_aq_search_container">
<div class="qa_section_heading" id="qa_aq_search_heading">Search</div>
<input class="qa_aq_search" placeholder="Type your query here"/>
</div>
<a id="qa_add_curated_question">Add New Question</a>
<ul class="qa_questions qa_aqs qa_waittheresmore" id="qa_article_questions">
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="267646" data-caid="268519" data-cqid="267663" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="1308725" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="39359" data-votes_down="6" data-votes_up="36">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">Can I do steam after just waking up?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_expert_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box">

<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="28945" data-caid="29818" data-cqid="28962" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="245722" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="24" data-votes_up="183">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">How many times a week should I do this?</div>

<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">You should steam your face no more than once a week. If your pores are particularly clogged, you can steam your face twice a week until your condition improves. Steaming your face too often can actually lead to more breakouts.  </div>

<div class="qa_q_txt question">After toning my face with lemon juice, do I wash it off and then moisturize? If so, how long do I leave the lemon juice on my face?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">

<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Yes, always rinse off the lemon juice. It's recommended that you keep the lemon juice on your face for 5-10 minutes and then rinse with cold water. If you experience any stinging at all, rinse immediately.</div>

<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">

<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="31114" data-caid="31987" data-cqid="31131" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="172242" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="17" data-votes_up="105">

<div class="qa_q_txt question">Can I wash my face afterwards with cold water?</div>

<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>

<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Yes, you can. Steaming your face helps open up pores while cold water will help close them back up. Consider washing or wiping your face with a towel after you use steam first though; this will help get rid of any surface dirt. </div>

<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="93694" data-caid="94567" data-cqid="93711" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="501555" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="10" data-votes_up="67">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>

<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">Is daily steaming good for acne and pimples on the face?</div>

<div class="qa_user_area">

<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Don't steam daily, as this can dry your face out and make your acne even worse. Limit your steaming to once every week, or every other week, depending on your skin type. If you happen to have very oily skin, then you might be able to steam every couple of days.</div>

<div id="summary_wrapper"><div id="summary_text">
<h2>Article Summary<a href="#" id="summary_close">X</a>
</h2>
<p>If you want to steam your face, bring 1 to 2 cups of water to a boil. While the water is heating, wash your face with a gentle cleanser. If you want an aromatherapy steam treatment, add fragrance oils or herbs after you take your water off the heat. Then, once the water is ready, drape a towel over your head and lean down so you can feel the steam on your face without it burning you. Relax and enjoy the treatment for about 5-10 minutes. <span id="summary_last_sentence">For more tips from out Beauty reviewer, including how to steam to relieve stress or get ready for bed, read on!</span><span class="sumpos_bottom" id="summary_position"></span></p>

			{ ref: 'large', srcset: [ root + 'large@1x.png 300w', root + 'large@2x.png 600w', root + 'large@3x.png 900w' ] },

            "@type": "HowToSection",

            "position": 1,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Bring a small pot of water to a boil. A basic steam involves nothing but water and your skin. It doesn't require much water. Fill up a small pot with 1 - 2 cups of water and bring it to a full boil.[1]"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Wash your face. While the water is heating up, wash your face using a gentle cleanser. Your pores will open wide, and if you have dirt or makeup on your skin, it could cause irritation.[2]\nDon't wash your face with an exfoliating scrub or harsh soap. Before a steam, it's best to wash with a very mild cleanser, to reduce the chance that the steam treatment will further irritate your skin.\nPat your face dry with a soft towel."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,

If you just want a quick steam, you can leave it in the pot. Place whatever vessel you're using on a few folded towels on top of a table.\n\nDon't pour the water into a plastic bowl. You don't want small plastic molecules getting involved in your facial steam.\nBe very careful that you do not burn yourself! If you decide to leave the water in the pot, then make sure to remove it from the heat source before using it."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 4,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Add essential oils or herbs. Now's the time to add essential oils or herbs to the water to make the treatment a little special. If you add oils or herbs, the steam treatment will double as an aromatherapy session, so it will be a 2-in-1 treatment. Just a few drops of essential oils goes a long way.[3]\nBe sure to add any extras after you've taken the water off the boil. Otherwise, the scents will quickly evaporate.\nIf you don't have any special oils or herbs, try tea! Put a few herbal tea bags in the water. Chamomile, mint, and chai all make excellent steams."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 5,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Steam your face with a towel over your head. Drape the towel over your head so that it drops down on either side of your face, trapping the steam so that it concentrates near your skin. Place your face close enough to the steaming water to feel it massaging your face, but not so close that your skin feels like it's burning or you're having trouble breathing fresh air.[4]\nA typical steam lasts about 10 minutes, so you may want to sit down while you do the treatment. However, keep in mind that you can receive many of the same benefits if you stop after 5 minutes.\nDon't steam your face for much longer than 10 minutes, especially if you have acne or other skin issues. Steaming causes the face to swell, and it can exacerbate acne if done for too much time."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 6,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Draw the dirt from your pores with a mask. The steam treatment leaves your pores wide open, making this the perfect time to draw out the dirt and other impurities. The best way to do so is to follow your steam treatment with a clay mask. Smooth the mask over your face and let it sit for 10-15 minutes. Wash it away with warm water and pat your face dry with a towel.[5]\nYou can purchase a clay mask in the beauty section of your grocery store, drug store, or large store, such as Target or Walmart.\nIf you don't have a clay mask, use plain honey or a combination of honey and oatmeal.\nIf you choose not to use a mask, you can simply wash your face with warm water after the steam treatment.\nDon't use a strong exfoliant on your skin after steaming, especially if you have acne. Since your face will be slightly swollen and your pores will be open, scrubbing it could cause it to become inflamed."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 7,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Tone your face. After you rinse your mask away, use a facial toner to help your pores close back up. Apply it to your face in gentle strokes using a cotton ball.\n\nLemon juice makes a great natural toner. Mix 1 tablespoon with 1 cup of water.\nApple cider vinegar is another great option. Mix 1 tablespoon with 1 cup of water."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 8,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Moisturize your face. Steam and heat cause the skin to dry out, so it's important to follow your treatment with a good moisturizer. Use one made with soothing oils, aloe and butters that will prevent your skin from getting too dry. Let the moisturizer completely absorb into your skin before applying makeup."
                    }
                }
            ]

Try one or more of the following herbs and oils for a soothing, stress-relieving steam:[8]\n\nHerbs: Lavender, lemon verbena, chamomile\n\nOils: Passionflower, bergamot, sandalwood"

For a rejuvenating steam, use one or more of these herbs and oils:\n\n\nHerbs: Lemon balm, peppermint, ginseng\n\nOils: Cedarwood, lemongrass, orange, grapefruit, eucalyptus[9]"
                    }
                },

                    "@type": "HowToStep",

                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,

Try using one or more of these herbs and oils to help you get to sleep more easily next time you have insomnia:[10]\n\nHerbs: Valerian, chamomile, lavender\n\nOils: Lavender, patchouli, geranium rose"
                    }
                }
            ]

content_html:
Bring a small pot of water to a boil. A basic steam involves nothing but water and your skin. It doesn't require much water. Fill up a small pot with 1 - 2 cups of water and bring it to a full boil.[1]
Wash your face. While the water is heating up, wash your face using a gentle cleanser. Be sure to remove all of your makeup and any dirt, oil or sweat that's sitting on the surface of your skin. It's important that your skin be clean when you steam it. Your pores will open wide, and if you have dirt or makeup on your skin, it could cause irritation.[2]
  • Don't wash your face with an exfoliating scrub or harsh soap. Before a steam, it's best to wash with a very mild cleanser, to reduce the chance that the steam treatment will further irritate your skin.
  • Pat your face dry with a soft towel.
Pour the steaming water into a bowl. If you're doing the steam treatment as part of an at-home spa treatment, pour it into a big, pretty ceramic or glass bowl. If you just want a quick steam, you can leave it in the pot. Place whatever vessel you're using on a few folded towels on top of a table.
  • Don't pour the water into a plastic bowl. You don't want small plastic molecules getting involved in your facial steam.
  • Be very careful that you do not burn yourself! If you decide to leave the water in the pot, then make sure to remove it from the heat source before using it.
Add essential oils or herbs. Now's the time to add essential oils or herbs to the water to make the treatment a little special. If you add oils or herbs, the steam treatment will double as an aromatherapy session, so it will be a 2-in-1 treatment. Just a few drops of essential oils goes a long way.[3]
  • Be sure to add any extras after you've taken the water off the boil. Otherwise, the scents will quickly evaporate.
  • If you don't have any special oils or herbs, try tea! Put a few herbal tea bags in the water. Chamomile, mint, and chai all make excellent steams.
Steam your face with a towel over your head. Drape the towel over your head so that it drops down on either side of your face, trapping the steam so that it concentrates near your skin. Place your face close enough to the steaming water to feel it massaging your face, but not so close that your skin feels like it's burning or you're having trouble breathing fresh air.[4]
  • A typical steam lasts about 10 minutes, so you may want to sit down while you do the treatment. However, keep in mind that you can receive many of the same benefits if you stop after 5 minutes.
  • Don't steam your face for much longer than 10 minutes, especially if you have acne or other skin issues. Steaming causes the face to swell, and it can exacerbate acne if done for too much time.
Draw the dirt from your pores with a mask. The steam treatment leaves your pores wide open, making this the perfect time to draw out the dirt and other impurities. The best way to do so is to follow your steam treatment with a clay mask. Smooth the mask over your face and let it sit for 10-15 minutes. Wash it away with warm water and pat your face dry with a towel.[5]
  • You can purchase a clay mask in the beauty section of your grocery store, drug store, or large store, such as Target or Walmart.
  • If you don't have a clay mask, use plain honey or a combination of honey and oatmeal.
  • If you choose not to use a mask, you can simply wash your face with warm water after the steam treatment.
  • Don't use a strong exfoliant on your skin after steaming, especially if you have acne. Since your face will be slightly swollen and your pores will be open, scrubbing it could cause it to become inflamed.
Tone your face. After you rinse your mask away, use a facial toner to help your pores close back up. Apply it to your face in gentle strokes using a cotton ball.
  • Lemon juice makes a great natural toner. Mix 1 tablespoon with 1 cup of water.
  • Apple cider vinegar is another great option. Mix 1 tablespoon with 1 cup of water.
Moisturize your face. Steam and heat cause the skin to dry out, so it's important to follow your treatment with a good moisturizer. Use one made with soothing oils, aloe and butters that will prevent your skin from getting too dry. Let the moisturizer completely absorb into your skin before applying makeup.
Do a cold relief steam. There's no clear evidence that steaming your face can help with a cold.[6] However, this is a common home remedy to relieve sinus pressure associated with a cold, and there is minimal evidence that it may be effective in some individuals.[7] If you want to try a cold relief steam, follow the steps above using one or more of the following herbs and essential oils:
  • Herbs: Chamomile, mint or eucalyptus
  • Oils: mint, eucalyptus or bergamot
Do a stress relief steam. Steaming soothes the soul as well as the skin, which is one of the reasons why it's a popular treatment at spas. A facial steam feels especially good when you're stressed out and can take the time to breathe in some wonderful scents while you sit back and relax. Try one or more of the following herbs and oils for a soothing, stress-relieving steam:[8]
  • Herbs: Lavender, lemon verbena, chamomile
  • Oils: Passionflower, bergamot, sandalwood
Do an invigorating steam. A steam can help you feel awake and refreshed if you do it first thing in the morning, particularly if you use scents that have an energizing effect. For a rejuvenating steam, use one or more of these herbs and oils:
  • Herbs: Lemon balm, peppermint, ginseng
  • Oils: Cedarwood, lemongrass, orange, grapefruit, eucalyptus[9]
Do a steam for sleep aid. Doing a steam a few minutes before you go to bed can help you relax and sleep peacefully. Try using one or more of these herbs and oils to help you get to sleep more easily next time you have insomnia:[10]
  • Herbs: Valerian, chamomile, lavender
  • Oils: Lavender, patchouli, geranium rose

If you decide to leave the water in the pot, then make sure to remove it from the heat source before using it. Add essential oils or herbs. Now's the time to add essential oils or herbs to the water to make the treatment a little special. If you add oils or herbs, the steam treatment will double as an aromatherapy session, so it will be a 2-in-1 treatment. Just a few drops of essential oils goes a long way. [3] Be sure to add any extras after you've taken the water off the boil. Otherwise, the scents will quickly evaporate. If you don't have any special oils or herbs, try tea! Put a few herbal tea bags in the water. Chamomile, mint, and chai all make excellent steams. Steam your face with a towel over your head. Drape the towel over your head so that it drops down on either side of your face, trapping the steam so that it concentrates near your skin. Place your face close enough to the steaming water to feel it massaging your face, but not so close that your skin feels like it's burning or you're having trouble breathing fresh air. [4] A typical steam lasts about 10 minutes, so you may want to sit down while you do the treatment. However, keep in mind that you can receive many of the same benefits if you stop after 5 minutes. Don't steam your face for much longer than 10 minutes, especially if you have acne or other skin issues. Steaming causes the face to swell, and it can exacerbate acne if done for too much time. Draw the dirt from your pores with a mask. The steam treatment leaves your pores wide open, making this the perfect time to draw out the dirt and other impurities. The best way to do so is to follow your steam treatment with a clay mask. Smooth the mask over your face and let it sit for 10-15 minutes. Wash it away with warm water and pat your face dry with a towel. [5] You can purchase a clay mask in the beauty section of your grocery store, drug store, or large store, such as Target or Walmart. If you don't have a clay mask, use plain honey or a combination of honey and oatmeal. If you choose not to use a mask, you can simply wash your face with warm water after the steam treatment. Don't use a strong exfoliant on your skin after steaming, especially if you have acne. Since your face will be slightly swollen and your pores will be open, scrubbing it could cause it to become inflamed. Tone your face. After you rinse your mask away, use a facial toner to help your pores close back up. Apply it to your face in gentle strokes using a cotton ball. Lemon juice makes a great natural toner. Mix 1 tablespoon with 1 cup of water. Apple cider vinegar is another great option. Mix 1 tablespoon with 1 cup of water. Moisturize your face. Steam and heat cause the skin to dry out, so it's important to follow your treatment with a good moisturizer. Use one made with soothing oils, aloe and butters that will prevent your skin from getting too dry. Let the moisturizer completely absorb into your skin before applying makeup. Do a cold relief steam. There's no clear evidence that steaming your face can help with a cold. [6] However, this is a common home remedy to relieve sinus pressure associated with a cold, and there is minimal evidence that it may be effective in some individuals. [7] If you want to try a cold relief steam, follow the steps above using one or more of the following herbs and essential oils: Herbs : Chamomile, mint or eucalyptus Oils : mint, eucalyptus or bergamot Do a stress relief steam. Steaming soothes the soul as well as the skin, which is one of the reasons why it's a popular treatment at spas. A facial steam feels especially good when you're stressed out and can take the time to breathe in some wonderful scents while you sit back and relax. Try one or more of the following herbs and oils for a soothing, stress-relieving steam: [8] Herbs : Lavender, lemon verbena, chamomile Oils : Passionflower, bergamot, sandalwood Do an invigorating steam. A steam can help you feel awake and refreshed if you do it first thing in the morning, particularly if you use scents that have an energizing effect. For a rejuvenating steam, use one or more of these herbs and oils: Herbs : Lemon balm, peppermint, ginseng Oils : Cedarwood, lemongrass, orange, grapefruit, eucalyptus [9] Do a steam for sleep aid. Doing a steam a few minutes before you go to bed can help you relax and sleep peacefully. Try using one or more of these herbs and oils to help you get to sleep more easily next time you have insomnia: [10] Herbs : Valerian, chamomile, lavender Oils : Lavender, patchouli, geranium rose
